Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Theory and Modelling of Non-Uniform Superconductors and Superfluids
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY

This CAREER award supports theoretical and computational research and education to investigate non-uniform superconducting states and their origin in novel superconductors and superfluid helium-3. Inhomogeneous states appear due to a complex interplay of multiple energy scales that lead to strong local modification of the quasiparticle spectrum and, macroscopically, to states with new symmetries. Such states are expected to play major roles in strongly correlated materials, systems with competing orders, and in the interface regions of small-scale devices.

The search for superconductors with higher critical temperature and better material characteristics has led to the discovery of new families of complex materials with exotic properties. Besides superconductivity, most display some kind of magnetic order which may significantly influence superconducting properties, and may provide or contribute to the pairing interaction that leads to superconductivity. Similar behavior may have also been observed in spin-triplet superfluid helium-3 in confined geometries. Experiments suggest many new condensate phases that are thought to be non-uniform.

This research will focus on presenting a comprehensive picture of non-uniform states in heavy fermion materials, superconductors without inversion center, FeAs-pnictides, and superfluid helium-3 films. New states and their thermodynamic, transport and magnetic properties will be studied in these systems, including strong-coupling and non-equilibrium phenomena. This project will advance understanding of the nature of new superconducting states of matter and help to link theory and experiment. The theoretical and numerical approach will be based on a quasiclassical formulation of the theory of superconductivity that will include magnetic degrees of freedom, multiple bands, and significant spin effects.

The results of this research may contribute to the realization of superconductor-based devices with superconducting interfaces. The study of magnetically active superconducting surfaces may influence appearance of new charge- and spin-coupled electronics. The research inspires demonstrations of the most influential principles of physics, such as symmetry and emerging complexity in many-particle systems. This forms the basis of the education component which involves the development of new courses on both graduate and undergraduate levels, and the development of an educational website with graphical demonstrations and links to other physics, chemistry and biological research conducted at Montana State University.

NONTECHNICAL SUMMARY

This CAREER award supports theoretical and computational research and education to investigate the nature of superconductivity in materials, that are highly non-uniform, have special arrangements of atoms, or display an interplay between magnetism and superconductivity. Superconductivity is an extraordinary state of electrons that can occur in some materials at sufficiently low temperatures. Unlike common wires made of, for example, copper, a superconductor can carry electric current without dissipation. Superconductors have other unusual properties that make them promising for applications in future electronic device technologies. This research will explore materials and conductions under which superconductivity can vary or can change from one superconducting state to another in the same material, for example in response to regions of magnetic order. This research may predict new phenomena in superconductors and in superfluids. Superfluids generalize the concept of superconductivity beyond electrons in a material to liquid states, for example those that that occur in liquid helium at temperatures approaching absolute zero. Superconductivity and more generally superfluidity is an intriguing state of matter that requires a quantum mechanical description and remains fertile not only intellectually in the discovery of new superconducting states and phenomena, but also for its potential applications, for example in new electronic devices and power transmission.

This research inspires demonstrations of some of the most powerful principles of condensed matter physics, such as symmetry and emerging complexity in many-particle systems. It also forms the basis of the education component which involves the development of new courses at both graduate and undergraduate levels, and the development of an educational website with graphical demonstrations and links to other physics, chemistry and biological research conducted at Montana State University.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Superconductivity and superfluidity are condensed states of matter appearing at very low temperatures, where interactions between particles and quantum effects step out onto the front stage. These phases of matter are characterized by coherent behavior of large number of electrons (or atoms in case of superfluid Helium), and unusual excitations (quasiparticles) that appear from such exotic ground state. 

 

The main goal of this project was to advance our understanding of superconductivity, subjected to extreme influences, or placed in unusual environments. Examples of such environments include constrained geometry (films, slabs), nonuniform states, proximity to interfaces, strong magnetic fields, competition between superconductivity and magnetism, multi-band systems. Under such conditions superconducting order becomes ‘stressed’, it ’buckles’ and gets modified, resulting in new quantum phases with new fundamental properties and new ‘particles’. We theoretically looked into these properties, particularly to understand how one can find the new phases in materials experimentally. The grant resulted in 14 publications and more than 25 conference presentations by PI, students and postdoc.

 

Discovery of magnetically-active multi-band iron-based superconductors has presented physicists with a challenge to understand the gap structures. Because of the complexity of these materials, multiple gap models could be realized. We calculated various physical observables, NMR frequency shift, thermal conductivity, specific heat, and in close collaboration with experimental groups we concluded that the most likely candidate in Ba(FeAs)2  system (P- and K-doped) is anisotropic gap of S+/- type, with accidental nodes. The gap nodes can appear and disappear depending on doping, they are located on flat parts of the Fermi surface. We provided examples of certain cases where one may mistakenly infer a different gap symmetry from data analysis based on simpler models. 

 

We have improved our numerical modeling of superconductors by considering effects of complex Fermi surfaces and multi-band electronic structure. This step is very important to establish solid experiment-theory symbiosis to correctly determine underlying properties of real materials. We applied the new computational techniques to heavy fermion superconductor CeCoIn5 and to family of FeSe-based materials. Our findings imply that a simultaneous analysis of the specific heat and thermal conductivity, with an emphasis on the low-energy sector, is needed to restrict potential pairing scenarios in multiband superconductors.

 

Theoretical treatment of heat current in nonuniform superconducting states is a very difficult problem because of multiple entangled effects in this phenomenon. We had a breakthrough in mathematical formulation of the problem by finding appropriate boundary conditions for relevant propagators, and were able to simultaneously consider effects of impurity scattering and Andreev branch conversion processes on the energy transport. This advancement provides a path towards further investigation of subgap surface states in superconductors using thermal conductivity. 

 

In Pauli-limited d-wave superconductors we discovered a mechanism that can lead to formation of magnetic order inside superconductor subjected to magnetic field, and determined most likely wave vectors of resulting spin waves. This can explain the mysterious phase in CeCoIn5 superconductor. We further showed that Andreev bound states in nonuniform superconductors can strongly enhance instability towards localized spin-density wave. We showed how these states have been seen in NMR relaxation rate in recent experiments in organic superconductors.

 

We also found that domain walls in superconducting order parameter can host bound collective modes and serve as ‘waveguides’. Such ‘superconductivity waves’ can have a very distinct spectrum with lower excitation thresholds and can help in detecting the nonuniform phases. 

 

Finally, a very important outcome of this project is establishment and growth of theoretical condensed matter group at Montana State University, first at MSU and in the region. From no such program prior to 2009, my group grew to several graduate students - some of them are getting close to PhD degree, some are just starting, - and a postdoctoral associate. Students have published papers, participated in international schools and conferences, and have been exposed to the forefront of research. I also developed superconductivity demonstrations and popular lectures to graduate, undergraduate, and regional middle and high school students introducing them to the world of theoretical physics, ultra-low temperatures and quantum mechanics. Superconductivity-based examples have been used in graduate and undergraduate courses taught by PI. Other teaching developments included inception of ‘Problem of the Week’ activity in the department, that encourages graduate and undergraduate students to think about nontrivial physics and math problems.
